utterances.translation: This happened a long, long time ago.
There was a small Son of Mink sitting on the rock.
“_č̓aaxstimcm̓it_” — this is how you say it when you tell a story.
He was looking over at the other shore across the strait.

utterances.transcript: ʔunackʔisitwaʔiš ʔaḥ, yaaqʷiɬ mamaɬn̓i [Juan de Fuca] waa.
utterances.translation: It was very close, the place that white men call Juan de Fuca.
He was looking at people at Port Angeles.
It was warm.
It might have been summer, and women were bathing.
Son of Mink had good vision.
He could see far, clearly seeing everything.

utterances.transcript: hixy̓aaʔaʔiswaʔiš ʔaḥ, qʷaxʔaamitii. qʷaʔaamitii qʷaa ʔaḥ.
utterances.translation: He was sitting there on the rock, probably doing like this. {with gesture}
And he did this. {with gesture of looking far away}
“Hmm, maybe I can go across the strait,” he said.

utterances.transcript: c̓aanititwaʔiš ʔaḥ qʷaasasa, c̓aanit, huʔap̓in c̓aa, c̓aa.
utterances.translation: There (in the strait) the current was always swift and going back and forth.

utterances.transcript: čuu, hitapʔiɬ č̓aaxstimcm̓it, wik ʔuucḥa, saaxyapanačšiƛ̓aqƛquu.
utterances.translation: Then, Son of Mink went across the strait but not for the purpose of going to far-off places.
Now minks are everywhere [although they weren’t numerous before].
He is very good at hiding behind the boulder [on the coast].
Finally, he had made it all the way.

utterances.transcript: ʔuuwaƛ č̓an̓iiʔat quuʔas n̓aacsa, č̓an̓iiʔat č̓aastimcm̓it.
utterances.translation: Son of Mink realized that people (the local people) couldn’t see him. (Mink saw that he couldn’t be seen.)
They didn’t know that it was him.
They could only see the figure of a person, i.e., human being.
Then, it became night.
Some days have passed.
“I keep talking to myself,” he said.
He was talking to himself.
He he was alone.
“I shall go on,” he said.
He departed.

utterances.transcript: yaacpanač, wikckʷii sasaaʔii sayaap̓inč ʔaḥ nism̓aʔi ʔunaḥitʔitq, [North America], yaaqʷiɬ mamaɬn̓i waa.
utterances.translation: He went for a walk: He didn’t go very far in this land, which the white men call North America.
he went to a beautiful level land, walking for some time on the beach.
It got dark.
He heard something — _txtxtxtxtx_ (splashing sound of fish jumping) — it sounded like this.
_txtxtxtxtxtx_ — “I wonder what that could be,” he said.
Mink woke up during this {with gesture} — maybe he extended his arms.
He started walking.
No. He never “walks” like us humans.
He does that — running on all fours.
He sat on the bank of the river and saw _txtxtxtxtx_ [fish jumping].
Son of Mink dove into the water.
he came up out of the water with a sockeye salmon in his mouth.
He kept diving until he had many and put them there on the ground.
He filleted fish.
There were many open shells (which he could use to fillet fish) on the stony beach.
He sharpened the knife and cut all [the fish] he had (whatever he might have had).

utterances.transcript: heey maaḥt̓iqiiɬ k̓uč čaškak, maḥt̓iičiƛuk, saač̓utcqiiʔisukʷitquu.
utterances.translation: Now, he was making a house quickly in a short period of time, and it became a house, which might have been a lean-to.
Little Mink made a fire, and put fish up on the rack (to dry).
Now, he is looking for something that would obstrutc the fire (from overburning).

utterances.transcript: hatksaap ʔunukʷititii maƛaak maƛaak, t̓aʔak ʔuušyuuyaʔat waaʔat, hatksaap.
utterances.translation: He rolled a log — who knows how big it was — which is sometimes called “drift logs”. He rolled it.
He was strong.

utterances.transcript: ʔučknaḥʔis č̓aastimcm̓it, k̓ʷitxak ʔuʔinkʷitʔis ʔaḥ qaaty̓apt̓aʔi.
utterances.translation: Son of Mink was very small. His legs were small.
Although he was all alone in the woods, sometimes there was a peculiar smell in his house.
Hm! (sniffing sound) — He would say “Hm!”
“Maybe there is a man living there,” he said.
He put his fish up on the rack (to dry).

utterances.transcript: ƛimkšiƛwaʔiš ʔuuyuʔaaɬšiƛwaʔiš quuʔas ḥaaɬ ʔiiḥ sukʷiʔatuk yuuɬʔaƛ̓aƛ.
utterances.translation: He woke up and realized that there was a big person. Suddenly he reached for something (the fish) and left with it.
It became daylight and there on the ground were footprints of a bear.
He cannot confront a bear because he is weak.
He cannot fight.
He (Mink) got sockeye by diving into the water and taking salmon in his mouth [to the shore].
Son of Wolf came.
He [Mink] heard him [Wolf] howling.
The little one [Mink] also howled.
_xuxuuu_ — this is how it sounded.
He didn’t know how [to howl].
He would sound like _uuwa xux xuu xuxuweey_.
Now, Wolf came.
He [Mink] made a bow and arrow.
Son of Mink didn’t like Son of Wolf.
He hated him because his teeth were huge.

utterances.transcript: wik. wik čamiḥta haʔuk, ʔašx̣tuup t̓aačt̓aača, x̣ax̣ x̣ax̣ x̣ax̣.
utterances.translation: He doesn’t eat properly — he chews on things which are not fit to eat — _xax xax xax_.
He has huge teeth.
He said, “You go to sleep!”
The mink knew that Son of Wolf was going to sleep.
He took his bow.
He shot Wolf here on the left side of the body — his heart.
He trembled slightly on the ground and died.
Son of Wolf was huge.

utterances.transcript: ʔin ʔana ʔiiḥ t̓uḥc̓iti. qatqʔatap, c̓uy̓itap.
utterances.translation: Since the biggest part of his [Wolf’s] body was his head, he [Mink] cut the head off and buried it in the ground.
He hid the corpse on the ground, where he sleeps — underneath the sleeping place.
There on the ground Son of Wolf was dead.
This happened soon after the incident: it was on the fourth day since then.
He [Mink] howled again: _hwo=wa_. He howled four times.
He said, _xuxuuwuwu xuu_.
“I, Son of Mink, am the one who killed Son of Wolf!” he said.
He wasn’t afraid because he was all by himself.
Now there came wolves; ten of them. It was a group of ten.
One wolf, probably the leader, howled: _woo=_.
There were no mountains (the land was completely flat).
Son of Mink had a comb.

utterances.transcript: saxčkšiƛ̓ixc̓aƛquuč ƛuyačiƛ n̓aačʔatu ʔuuktis ḥaaɬ puuɬʔii, c̓aʔak.
utterances.translation: The little one would comb his hair to get pretty by looking at his reflection in the pool of water or the river.
The little one (Mink) was looking down into the water and combing.
His (Mink’s) hair was never sticking out: his hair was always as if it was combed neatly — like this. {with picture?}
He wanted them (wolves) to be unaware of him.
Now, the leader [of wolves] spoke.
“You killed Son of Wolf!” he said.
“m-mm,” he said, “I didn’t do it.”

utterances.transcript: t̓iʕas hiʔiis ḥaaɬ, ʔatquu hiiɬc̓apuɬa ḥaa qʷayaac̓ikm̓itckʷi.
utterances.translation: He was sitting there on the ground. There was the corpse of Wolf underneath.
He (Wolf) is dead now.
They (wolves) surrounded him (Mink).
He said to him, “We shall kill you.”
He hid, you know, he had his bow hidden.

utterances.transcript: hitaatuʕiḥtap šaʔiḥtimʔi, yaaqḥʷʼaɬʔitq qaḥsaap, qʷayaac̓ikm̓it. haptsaap.
utterances.translation: He removed the arrowhead which he used to kill Son of Wolf from the arrow, and hid it.
He might have burned the bow.
[So] there was nothing to be seen.

utterances.transcript: haax̣aa, ƛ̓upiičiʔaƛ. ƛ̓upaa, qʷaaʔaƛ ʔaḥʔaa, qʷayac̓iik ƛ̓upy̓iiḥa.
utterances.translation: Now it became warm. It was so warm that the wolves were sweating like this.

utterances.transcript: čuu, waaʔaƛ č̓aaxstimcm̓it, [You are surrounded by the wolf. You had no way of try to escape. You killed him!] qaḥsaapʔick.
utterances.translation: “Now,” the wolf said to Son of Mink, “you are surrounded by wolves. You have no way of escaping. You killed him!”
“m-mm,” he might have said.

utterances.transcript: ḥaa, ƛ̓upy̓iiḥaƛ waa qʷis qʷaaʔamitiiʔaɬ, ƛ̓upy̓iiḥa. sweating.
utterances.translation: [While the wolves were holding Mink in captivity,] He (Mink) was sweating and they (wolves) were also sweating.

utterances.transcript: qʷisʔaƛquuč ʔaḥ kiššiƛ. c̓aʔatu ḥaaɬ ƛ̓upmis.
utterances.translation: When they shook their body, sweat rolled down their hides.
“Open up! You (wolves) make openings!” he (Mink) said.
“You people step aside and let there be space,” he said.
“You are telling a lie!” they (wolves) said to him (Mink).

utterances.transcript: ʔaa, y̓uuqʷaaʔap̓i ʔaḥ ʔucaqc̓uʔi waaʔaƛ, qʷicpaaʔitq c̓aʔakʔi, c̓aa ʔaḥ ʔaya hisit.
utterances.translation: “You do the same [break the circle] on this side also,” he said — [he was pointing] towards the side of the river — the river where there were many sockeye.

utterances.transcript: ʔunw̓iiƛ yaaqƛ qʷayaac̓ikm̓it ʔin ʔaniic̓ap̓at t̓uḥc̓iti,
utterances.translation: The reason why he hated Son of Wolf was that the wolf only fed him fish heads.
The only thing they fed him was the snout of the fish.
That’s how wolves eat. They never eat the whole fish.
“Well then, I will sing for you,” he said.
“Do you have a song?” he (Wolf) said.
“Yes.” [Mink answered.]
He sang,

utterances.transcript: ʔaniyas ʔaniyas [hoo hoo hoo] ʔaniyas ʔaniyas [hoo hoo hoo] n̓upc̓iqiiyasquus huyuuɬquus, c̓iḥatiiyasquus huyuuɬʔaqƛ, waa
utterances.translation: [Song] “If only I _ho ho ho_; if only I _ho ho ho_; if I had one on my shoulder, I would dance; if I had an arrow on my shoulder, I will dance,” he sang.
“Do another song,” they said. “Don’t you have another one?”

utterances.transcript: ʔaniyas ʔaniyas [hoo hoo hoo] ʔaniyas ʔaniyas [hoo hoo hoo] mustatiiyasquus huyuuɬquus
utterances.translation: [Song] “If only I _ho ho ho_; if only I _ho ho ho_; if I had a bow on my shoulder, I would dance.”

transcript.en: What he meant was he wanted a bow and an arrow.

utterances.translation: What he meant was he wanted a bow and an arrow.
utterances.trs-en: What he meant was he wanted a bow and an arrow.

utterances.translation: He was singing.
[Song] “If only I reach _ho_…”

utterances.transcript: qʷaaʔamitii [he had his bow like that.]
utterances.translation: This is how he did — he had his bow like that.

utterances.transcript: ʔaniyas ʔaniyas [hoo hoo hoo] n̓upxc̓iqiiyasquus huxyuuɬquus,
utterances.translation: [Song] “If only I reach _ho ho ho_; if only I reach _ho ho ho_; if I had one on my shoulder, I would dance.”
Son of Mink is about to kill the leader of all the wolves that is all white.
Now he is starting to dance.
The wolves were fascinated (by Mink’s dance).
[While he is dancing,] He (Mink) would move back and forth [toward the head chief].
The wolves were sitting there on the ground.
The path for his desperate escape (the path through which he is going to run for dear life — without taking direction: lit. ‘going for death’) has opened up.
He was going to run frantically.
His only hope was the river. (He was only counting on the river.)
[Song] “If only I _ho ho ho_…”
He closed his eye (to take an aim) like this and took his bow.
It was a direct hit.
_q̓ʷa:xtii_ ran.
_q̓ʷa:xtii_ has many names.
He ran and splash! [jumped into the water].
The wolves thought that mink would probably go downstream with the current.
Mink was smart.
He swam under water.
_Phoo!_, Son of Mink broke wind every once in a while [while he was swimming].
He always breaks wind.
Son of Mink farts all the time.

utterances.transcript: xaw kapxšiʔat ʔaḥ hinusaʔic̓aƛ ḥuu kʷisaqsʔi.
utterances.translation: Poof! He got out of breath and landed there on the other side of the river.

utterances.transcript: ḥuu hiɬʔaƛ qʷayac̓iikʔi ʔaya [down the river]
utterances.translation: There were many wolves way down there — down river.

utterances.transcript: [hoo hoo] waaʔaƛ. ʔaḥkuuseeš, tušaakitʔii. waaʔaƛ. waamitii.
utterances.translation: “Heey!” he said, “I am here, you dead meat!” he might have said.
“Whew, that was close!” the mink might have said.
The wolves started to swim.
_q̓ʷaaxtii_ ran.
He had many names: his brother was called _kʷatyaat_.
He was running.
He came upon a beautiful place.
He took the medicine bottle from his little bag.
They were on the other side of the river.

utterances.transcript: c̓ixčiʔaƛ ʔaḥʔaa qʷis, ʔiiwačiʔim c̓aʔak. ʔiiwačiʔim.
utterances.translation: He splashed it (the medicine) like this {with gesture of shaking a bottle} [into a little creek], [casting a spell] “You become a large river!”
Now the current started to flow.

utterances.transcript: ʔuḥʔat. ʔuḥmatak̓aƛ yaaqʷiɬʔitq Columbia waaʔat, [Columbia River].
utterances.translation: This is the one — this is probably the one that it is called Columbia river.
Then he took out his comb and did this {with gesture of scratching the ground with the comb}.
[And then] it became land and mountain range and obstructions.
_q̓ʷaaxtii_ heard [howling] _woo=_ at a distance.
[But] he didn’t answer to the howl.
They (the wolves) were following _q̓ʷaaxtii_′s path.
They were running and would smell (for _q̓ʷaaxtii_) like this {with gesture of smelling on the ground} every once in a while.
They could smell clearly the odor (of _q̓ʷaaxtii_) since he kept farting.
They were running.
Then Son of Mink was going to trick them.
He pushed his leg straight down on the ground on this side.

utterances.transcript: ʔuuḥʷʼaɬʔaƛ qacaasʔatʔi qʷisʔaƛ ʔaḥ, ʔuukʷiɬ ʔaḥ, c̓isimcʔi,
utterances.translation: With his left foot he did this to the soil {with a gesture of squeezing the soil by turning the leg left and right}.
[And] it became a mountain range — a huge mountain range.

utterances.transcript: kamatqšiʔaƛ wiikst̓iiḥ ʔuncukʷitii, n̓upčiiɬ, ʔaƛčiiɬ, qacc̓ačiɬ, muučiiɬ, ḥayučiɬitquu. kamatquk.
utterances.translation: He ran for dear life, for some time — one, two, three, four days, or it could have been ten days. He ran.
He didn’t get any sleep.
Now he took a rest and took out his medicine oil.

utterances.transcript: c̓ičiƛ ʔaḥ qʷis ʔucpaaʔaƛ ʔaḥ tuč̓iicpaʔi, [east side].
utterances.translation: He sprinkled the oil doing like this {with the gesture of sprinkling liquid from a bottle} on this side — east side.
Now he saw large lakes appear there.
He started running.
He could have started from here — the Puget Sound area.

utterances.transcript: huʔacaqsit, qʷaaqčiik̓aƛ ʔaḥʔaa ʕumaaʔap, ʕuy̓aakʔi, ƛaqmisukʔi.
utterances.translation: He went to the other side of the sound, running this way {with the gesture of stooping over and sprinkling oil by shaking the bottle in his hand} and let his medicine oil run onto the ground.
It also became a river.
Now he (Mink) ran [taking a human figure].
They (the wolves) caught up with him again.

utterances.transcript: huḥtak̓aƛ̓iš č̓aastimcm̓it q̓ʷaaxtii ʔin p̓usaak̓aƛ qʷayac̓iikʔi.
utterances.translation: Son of Mink, _q̓ʷaaxtii_, knew that the wolves were tired.
He stopped and urinated.
“You become salty,” he said, and it [the pond of urine] got large [into a body of salt water].
He ran.
The wolves came to the place.
The wolves got thirsty and drank the water.

utterances.transcript: qʷaaʔamitii wiiy̓a c̓ic̓uqšiƛ, ʔaanaḥʷʼaaɬ č̓up̓atʔi naaqnaaqa.
utterances.translation: When drinking, they never drink with a utensil, rather they only use their tongue to drink.
He ran for dear life.
They (the wolves) are in close pursuit.
He arrived at what appeared to be an island or an offshore reef.
The little one (Mink) was running.
Son of Mink stopped and dug holes.
He squatted on the ground again and farted, Poop!, to cover up, to make it (his route) obscure.

utterances.transcript: qʷaaʔapʔaqƛ̓ick ʔaḥʔaa qum̓aa kʷiisqšiƛ ʔum̓aack ʔiqsiɬa.
utterances.translation: (Mink was saying to himself) “Year after year [= as long as you live] you (Mink himself) will be doing the same thing (farting on the ground).”
He swam across channels and made many mountains.
He went so far — wherever it might have been — by referring to the position of the sun.
The sun has changed its position [from his right side] and now it’s on this side [on his left side] of him [as he entered the different time zone].
Although we are on this side {with gesture} of the sun.
It [the sun] moved to his left side.
It [the sun] was in the southeast.
He saw the sun change its position to the left.
We don’t know exactly where he might have been.

utterances.transcript: kʷiisḥi ʔaḥ n̓aasʔi, yaaqʷiɬʔitq mamaɬn̓i [time zone] waa.
utterances.translation: Now the time of the day, or what white people call the “time zone”, is different.
Son of Mink went back along the same trail.
He ran.
The wolves went far without finding him (Mink).
He went back all the way along the same route although he swam across.
It was so close.
“Land, move far away a little!”
He was running on his way back on the same route.
He stopped every once in a while to take a nap.
He closed his eyes.
Now he woke up.
He was running along the mountains.
He dove into the water every once in a while so that they wouldn’t find out the route he took.
He went far sometimes going up stream [although it was easier and faster to go downstream].
The wolves did not know what Son of Mink _q̓ʷaaxtii_, was doing.
And he found another pack of wolves.

utterances.transcript: wik ʔiiḥ, ʔučknaḥʔis qʷaaʔiitq čamiḥtaʔi qʷayac̓iik
utterances.translation: They were not big; they were much smaller than the real wolves.
They might have been cubs.
They recognized him [as Mink] while he was on the rock.
“Is is you, Son of Mink!” they said to him.
“No. My name is _kapkimyis_,” he said.
“My name is _kapkimyis_.”
He took his younger brother’s name.
“It’s you!” they said to him.
It’s you! umum
“I am not! I am not! I am not!”
Son of Mink shifted his body a little on the beach.
There he saw a crack [in a boulder].
Chuq! He quickly slipped through into the hole. Chuq!
Those people [the wolves are taking human shape now] poked at him repeatedly with sticks.
They poked into the hole and [the mink cried], “_xaw xaw_…”
He was dying.
He saw limpets stuck on the rock surface above him [looked as if they were suspended in the air].
He bit out the innards (out of the limpets) and wrapped them around the pole.
“Look! He is dead! _q̓ʷaaxtii_ is dead!” they said.
“He is dead!”
He heard them paddling the canoes.
They (the wolves) had canoes.
_Wooox_, he took a peek.
“You only have innards of limpets on the pole!” he said.

utterances.transcript: haa haa ʔaaxʔaniḥtaak, haa haa c̓iic̓iiyupuuk, huu huu p̓aap̓aʕimʔay, waa
utterances.translation: He sang, “You only have innards of limpets on the pole!”
He might have said, “you SOB.”
“You, dirty scum!” he said.
Son of Mink ran into the woods.
He got hungry in the early morning.
He went down the rocks toward the water and there were many little crabs.
“Well! You people thought I was dead, didn’t you!” he (Mink) said.
They call him “the on with a bad mouth”.
″[You thought] the one with a bad mouth was dead!” [Mink yelled at them sarcastically].

utterances.transcript: ʔee qaḥtak qʷaqʔisqač̓a waaʔaƛ̓at hask̓aamacʔi [little crabs].
utterances.translation: “We thought you were dead!” said to him, the little crabs.
“I’ll wipe all of these little ones!” he said.

utterances.transcript: tuxʷiičiƛ haʔukšiƛ, [xaw xaw xaw] pisatšiʔaƛ ʔaḥ.
utterances.translation: He jumped on them (the little crabs) and ate them all over the place.
“Oh, let me live,” they (the crabs) said to him (Mink).
“I didn’t say anything bad.

utterances.transcript: ƛuƛuɬwasʔaaɬ suutiɬ, waaʔaƛ c̓awaak. qʷiqitiit ḥaakʷaaƛ.
utterances.translation: I always say nice things to you,” said one — maybe it was a girl.
No crabs were there any more.
None survived but one.
There were some that survived (the killing) in the same way before and one of them (?) found another (survivor).
He (Mink) didn’t eat them and the crabs became two.
This is how he (Mink) went back to the other side.
They (the wolves) didn’t catch him.
Once again Son of Mink escaped.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaƛitwaʔiš ɬučnaakšiʔaƛ. wik, ʔuʔup̓iqš. ʔuʔup̓iqš muuḥinƛas.
utterances.translation: Then, it is said, he got married — no, had an affair with Sawbill Woman.
Sawbill Woman had a baby.

utterances.transcript: hiitinqsaʔee ḥaawim̓eet ʔaaniik suuw̓aas t̓aan̓ee, ɬicw̓isee ɬicw̓isee muuḥinƛas. waaʔaƛquuč.
utterances.translation: “Come down to the beach, Son of Loon. Because you might be responsible for Sawbill Woman bearing an illegitimate child,” they (family of the Sawbill Woman) said.

utterances.transcript: haaciqšiʔaƛquuč haa nay̓aqakʔi suuɬ muuḥinƛas ḥaaɬ “[taa taa taa],” wawaa.
utterances.translation: [When people came in response to the Sawbill family’s request,] the baby wouldn’t be satisfied, grabbing on to his mother, saying ”[I want my] Daddy, Daddy, Daddy.”
The girl kept shaking her head slowly [indicating that they were not the child’s father].
Sometimes the baby covered his face.
“You are not my father,” the baby told many [that came in response to the Sawbill family’s request].

utterances.transcript: ʔiinaxy̓aƛ ḥaaw̓iiḥaƛ, hiyiqsatḥ, naaḥtač ƛutƛuuɬʔi ḥaaw̓iiḥaƛ, naaḥtačm̓it, ḥuksumm̓it, muučʔaaʔa, qʷištuupʔitq.
utterances.translation: Many of them, dressed young men, coming from all over the place: handsome young men — mallards, geese, grebes, and all other kinds of bird.
They exhausted all the possible people on the beach from all over the place. (They asked everybody on the beach from all the places about the baby.)
Now there is only one [possibility] left. He is the only possibility.

utterances.transcript: hitinqsaʔee č̓aastimcm̓eet qʷaaxyiik ʔaani suxʷ̓aas t̓an̓ee.
utterances.translation: “Come down to the beach, Son of Mink, because you might be responsible for the child.”
“Sawbill Woman gave birth to an illegitimate child.” [they sang, and the baby also called him] “Daddy, Daddy, Daddy.”
Qwaaxtii went down to the beach and walked with smile on his face.

utterances.transcript: yaacšiƛ, waa ʔatquu wiiy̓a yaacuk. muuxkmuukʷaʔis.
utterances.translation: We say “walk”, although it (Mink) never “walks”, but rather “runs on fours”.
That’s how he walks. {with gesture}

utterances.transcript: nay̓iik t̓an̓aʔisʔi ʔuyaasiɬa, [taa taa taa taa].
utterances.translation: Suddenly the child acted differently [because he recognized Son of Mink as his fatehr and got excited to see his father].
Son of Mink held the child.
He got married to very beautiful Sawbill Woman.
Now, he set up a household and [said] “Let’s go out for food,” and would go out for food (fishing).
Son of Mink would fill the canoe with small purple sea urchins [which can be collected only at low tide] all the time even at high tide.

utterances.transcript: ʔaniya ʔuuy̓ip̓at ḥiix ḥaay̓aaƛquu ḥuuɬ ʔax̣yuuʔaƛquu nuusčii, t̓uc̓up.
utterances.translation: The only time you can gather things from low tide, such as various kinds of sea urchins, is when the tide is low.

utterances.transcript: ḥačiy̓imštupʔi, p̓aʕim, ʔaya, ʕiičnuu ʔuḥuk haʔum.
utterances.translation: Food from low tide, such as limpet, various kinds of bullhead, was his food.
Mink dove into the water. He was diving.
He was away for a long time. She (Sawbill Woman) could see him because the water was clear.
He ate and ate [sea urchins unde the water].
Apparently (?) he did the wrong thing.
He ate the sea urchin.
He came back ashore and said “I didn’t catch any.”
“There is nothing!”
“What? Go back in the water!” She (Sawbill Woman) pushed him into the water and he (Mink) dove in.
Her mood changed and she started to hate him.
Sawbill Woman started to hate him.

utterances.transcript: sit̓a qʷaa naasqnaasqʷa, puuputq̓ʷisaƛ waxckʷiʔaƛ, bbbbb [bubble going up].
utterances.translation: He moved his tail left and right this way and air bubbles went up to the surface: he has broken wind.
She left on the canoe but didn’t go far.
“I divorce you!” she said.
“You are dirt! You are stupid!” she might have said to him.
Sawbill Woman was paddling the canoe away but didn’t go far.
The child was moving his elbows up and down.
We call the baby bird “_qačaa_”.
[Because] they fly moving the wings up and down.
